answers.answer: Woops, sorry.  Actually I answered this previously, but apparently Medhelp accidentally cut me off by going offline to do upgrades.  It's what I get for doing this late at night  :)So, I have certainly had kittens eat litter, although I can't think how that could be contagious.  I usually just try to discourage it as much as I can and wait for them to grow out of it.One of our cats had a very similar skin condition recently and we ended up giving him yucca extract, which is a powdered dietary supplement.  It has, among other things, anti-inflammatory properties and the problem cleared up.  I've had good results with yucca in the past, as well.The only other thing I would recommend would be to get a second opinion.  Particularly if you are not 100% sure about the vet you went to.  You can sometimes get a very different diagnosis and treatment by going to a second vet.Good luck.  Sorry about the mix-up.  I hope you'll keep us posted.

question: We took in a kitten that showed up on our doorstep. He appeared healthy; except had bald spots on ears and ate the Swheat Scoop Litter. I changed the litter so he wouldn't eat it, and took him to the vet. The vet has tested for ringworm, parasites, worms, FIV, diabetes, mites, etc. Everything has come back negative. We know it's not a food allergy, because despite isolation now 2 of my other cats are losing hair just on the ears and are going after the litter. They've never tried to eat anything but food or plants before. The spots are getting bigger, but they aren't red, itchy, crusted over, or anything - just no hair.Any help you can give is greatly appreciated.Thanks!
title: Bald Spots on ears and eats litter
